newsitem.title: GERMANY: James Bond to drive BMW car in new film.
newsitem.headline: James Bond to drive BMW car in new film.

text.p: James Bond, Britain's famous screen secret agent, this week picked up the keys to his new company car -- a $100,000 top-of-the-line BMW 750i saloon that he will drive in a new film slated for release in December.

The car is a regular production model but will have "extras" not traditionally available to the public. They will be added by 007's creative assistant "Q," who develops devices to help get the movie hero out of trouble.
"It will look like the standard production vehicle," ," Gordon Arnell, spokesman for Eon Productions, said in a telephone interview.
"But when it is delivered to Bond by Q, it will have all sorts of optional extras."
Eon Productions of Britain told Reuters on Wednesday it had agreed with Bayerische Motoren Werke AG of Munich for Bond again to drive a BMW in the latest 007 adventure.
The BMW saloon, which is "aspen silver" in colour, was first used in filming on Tuesday at Stansted airport near London for the film, which has been titled "Tomorrow Never Dies", the 18th Bond film.

The movie is billed as a "high-octane tale of media power as a lethal weapon" and pits Pierce Brosnan as the lady-killer Bond against Jonathan Pryce, a mad media mogul who considers triggering World War Three to garner higher television ratings.

BMW has scored another marketing coup in winning the deal for Bond to drive one of its vehicles. He drove a BMW Z3 in his last film, GoldenEye, in a deal that required BMW to include the Bond character in advertising campaigns about the car.

The carmaker received a massive wave of publicity for the Z3 roadster and its link to the high-flying character, sparking heavy sales orders for the vehicle and also a new wave of carmakers turning to Hollywood to expose their products.

A BMW spokesman declined comment on the deal other than to confirm that the German carmaker had delivered saloons to Eon in mid-February for use in the film. He also confirmed the price tag of a 750i -- 173,000 marks including taxes.
Arnell declined to comment on terms of the deal with BMW, which has had a long relationship with Bond films since the early 1980s production of "Octopussy".

The decision to continue using a car made by BMW, which also owns British-based Rover, will certainly prompt some fans of Bond to criticise the commercialisation of the character as well as to question why he was not driving a British vehicle.

A member of Britain's parliament, Geoffrey Robinson, who is also a former chief executive of British carmaker Jaguar, had called on Eon to back the British car industry. He once drove an Aston Martin DB5.
Many famous names in the British car industry, such as Aston Martin, Jaguar and Bentley, lobbied hard for the opportunity to get their latest models into the film.
"You can be sure that most of the major car manufacturers have been on to us in one form or another," he said.
